data.name: Introduction
entries: Are you unsatisfied with the rules for firearms in the DMG? Do you like Matthew Mercer's Gunslinger but found yourself longing for a full class with even more flavourful options? Reddit users u/Ujio21 and /u/xQF13 have got you covered with the {@class gunslinger|u21gs|Gunslinger} class and brand new rules for firearms, detailed below.

entries.name: Gunslinger
entries: Waking up to a goblin ambush, a human reaches for the pistol she always keeps at her side. She leaps to her feet and begins to fire, blasting the nearest goblin away before he can strike.

A gnome sighs to himself in satisfaction as he puts the final screw into his masterpiece: a massive rifle, almost twice as tall as he is. He loads it and tests it out on a nearby tree. The ensuing blast knocks the gnome off of his feet. He stumbles upright, grinning as he sees the tree topple over from the hit.

Gunslingers are masters of the firearm, using them to devastating effect on the battlefield. A gunslinger uses a steady trigger finger and technical skill to provide cover fire for her companions and cripples opponents with deadly special shots.

entries.name: Creating a Gunslinger
entries: Gunslingers thrive on the outskirts of civilization, both famous and infamous in the more free-spirited areas of the world. Talk with your DM about an appropriate origin for your Gunslinger. Do you live in a city, where your weapons are possibly outlawed? Or, perhaps, you come from the frontier, where your kind are common and the laws, less so.

How did you acquire your first gun? Did your fervor for invention lead you to create something more powerful than you know? Did a demon trade this knowledge for the promise of a favor? Maybe you killed a vengeful foe and took your gun off his dead body.

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: You can make a gunslinger quickly by following these suggestions. First, put your highest ability score in Dexterity, followed by Intelligence or Charisma, depending on the Trail you intend to take at 3rd level. Second, choose the outlander background.

Ammunition (range 10/20), capacity 2, light, misfire 3, reload, scatter

entries.name: Firearm Proficiency
entries: In this homebrew firearms are neither simple or martial weapons, and comprise a category of their own. Characters in most D&D worlds wouldn't have a proficiency in this category, aside from those of the {@class gunslinger|u21gs|Gunslinger} class. It's up to the DM to decide whether a character has proficiency with a firearm.

During their downtime, characters can use the {@book training rules|PHB|8|Training} in the Player's Handbook to acquire proficiency, assuming that they have enough ammunition to keep the weapons working while mastering their use.

entries.name: Firearm Properties
entries: Firearms have special properties related to their use, as shown in the Firearms table.

entries.name: Ammunition
entries: You can use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack only if you have ammunition to fire from the weapon. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack. Loading a one-handed weapon requires a free hand. The ammunition of a firearm is destroyed upon use.
If you use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a melee attack, you treat the weapon as an improvised weapon. A sling must be loaded to deal any damage when used in this way.

entries.name: Broken
entries: A broken firearm cannot be fired until it is repaired. To repair a broken firearm, you may use an action to attempt a tinker's tools ability check with a DC equal to 10 plus the weapon's base misfire score. On a success, the weapon is no longer considered broken.

entries.name: Capacity
entries: A firearm's capacity is the number of shots it can hold at one time. When a firearm has been fired a number of times equal to its capacity, it must be reloaded before firing again.

entries.name: Misfire
entries: If your natural roll for a gun attack falls at or below the misfire score of the gun you are using, you suffer a misfire. Your attack misses, any ammo you used in the attack is expended, and your gun becomes broken. You must repair a broken gun before using it.

entries.name: Reload
entries: Reloading a gun replaces your next attack you would make with the firearm, refilling the ammunition in the gun up to its capacity. If you prefer, you may instead use an action to reload your firearm.

entries.name: Scatter
entries: Firearms with this property shoot pellets in a cone out to their long range increment. All creatures within the cone must make a Dexterity saving throw (DC equal to the 8 + the shooter's Dexterity modifier + the shooter's Proficiency modifier), taking full damage on a failed save, or half damage on a successful one. Creatures outside of the firearm's short range have advantage on this saving throw. If the shooter is not proficient with firearms, all creatures attempt the saving throw roll with advantage.

entries.name: Silenced
entries: When fired, a silenced weapon makes no more noise than a bowshot.

entries.name: Ammunition and Water
entries: If your ammunition becomes wet, there is a 50 chance it becomes a blank. You roll a d100 to determine if a wet piece of ammo is a blank when it is fired. On a {@chance 50|1-50}, it's a blank and doesn't fire.

entries.name: Firearms and Water
entries: If your firearm becomes wet, you must use your tinker's tools to disassemble the gun and clean it before it is operational again. Disassembling your gun does not require an ability check, but it does require a set of tinker's tools. You cannot load or fire a firearm underwater without magical aid, unless otherwise stated.

entries.name: Noise
entries: When fired, a firearm makes a loud sound, much like two stones crashing together at high speed. This sound is easily heard by any creature within \u00bc mile of the gunshot.

entries.name: Special Firearms
entries: Firearms with special rules are described here.

entries.name: Derringer
entries: A small pistol created for surprise attacks at close range, the derringer is an assassin's best friend. Derringers grant their wielder advantage on {@skill Sleight of Hand} checks to draw, and can attack from within 5 feet without disadvantage.

optionalfeature.name: Blood in the Eyes
entries: Spend a grit point as a reaction if an enemy scores a hit on you to make a ranged attack against the triggering enemy.

optionalfeature.name: Blossom
entries: Spend one grit to make a firearm attack against multiple targets within 15 feet of you.  One grit point for each extra target.  You must have as many loaded shots for each target.

optionalfeature.name: Buck Up
entries: As a bonus action on your turn, you can expend one hit die to gain temporary hit points equal to the number rolled on the die + your Constitution modifier.

optionalfeature.name: Bullet Time
entries: You can spend one grit point to take the Dodge action as a bonus action on your turn.

optionalfeature.name: Curve the Bullet
entries: You spend one grit point to make a shot against a target you do not have direct line of sight on or is behind cover.

optionalfeature.name: Disarm
entries: When you make a firearm attack against a creature, you can expend one grit point to attempt to shoot an object from their hands. On a hit, the creature suffers normal damage and must succeed on a Strength saving throw or drop 1 held object of your choice and have that object be pushed 10 feet away from them.

optionalfeature.name: Fancy Footwork
entries: Spend a grit point to take the Disengage action as a bonus action.

optionalfeature.name: Hamper
entries: You attempt to hobble the enemy’s movement using a grit point when making a firearm attack. The target must make a Dexterity saving throw. If it fails, its movement speed is reduced by half and it makes Dexterity saving throws with disadvantage until the end of its next turn.

optionalfeature.name: Intercept
entries: When an enemy makes a ranged attack within your firearm's range, you can expend one grit point in order to use a reaction in an attempt to shoot the object out of the air. Make a ranged weapon attack against the projectile. These projectiles have an AC equal to the attack roll of the creature that shot or cast them. If you succeed, the attack automatically fails as you strike it and either destroys the projectile (in the case of ammunition) or knocks it off course (in the case of a thrown weapon).

optionalfeature.name: Lightning Reload
entries: Spend a grit point to reload a firearm as a free action.

optionalfeature.name: Marking Shot
entries: Spend a grit point when making an attack, if the attack succeeds the target becomes wounded and all attacks made against that creature have advantage until the start of your next turn.

optionalfeature.name: Quick Clear
entries: Spend a grit point to clear a misfired gun as a bonus action

optionalfeature.name: Ricochet
entries: Spend a grit point when you miss with an attack using a firearm and you do not have disadvantage on the roll, you can use your bonus action to reroll the attack roll to hit another target within 30 ft of the original target.

optionalfeature.name: Sprint
entries: You can spend a grit point to take the Dash action as a bonus action on your turn.

optionalfeature.name: Slinger's Luck
entries: Spend a grit point to reroll a saving throw or skill check.

optionalfeature.name: Sureshot
entries: When you make a firearm attack against a creature, you can expend one grit point to remove any disadvantage imposed on the attack roll.

optionalfeature.name: Take the Bullet
entries: As a reaction when a creature within 15 feet of you is targeted by a ranged attack, you can spend a grit point to dive in the way of the attack. You move next to the creature and become the target of the attack. If you are hit, you can subtract your Dexterity modifier from the damage taken

optionalfeature.name: Trip
entries: When you spend a grit point you attempt to knock the target prone. The target must make a Strength saving throw or be knocked prone.

optionalfeature.name: Tumbleweed
entries: When you are the target of a ranged attack or you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity saving throw and there is cover within 15 feet of you, you can spend a grit point to move up to 15 feet using your reaction. You must end this movement in cover.

optionalfeature.name: Utility Shot
entries: Spending a grit point you can quickly and precisely shoot objects. As an action, you can make a firearm attack targeting a Tiny object within the firearm’s range which isn’t being worn or carried, such as a rope, chain, belt, wooden rod, candle, bottle, or lock. This object is considered to have an AC of 10. On a hit, a nonmagical object is destroyed instantly and a weapon or magical object is flung 15 feet away.

optionalfeature.name: Warning Shot
entries: Spend a grit point to fire a shot into the air.  Any enemies within thirty feet that can hear your shot must make a Wisdom saving throw or be frightened until the start of your next turn.  Once a target is affected by or saves from this affect they are immune to it for the next 24 hours.

default: (a) an {@item explorer's pack|phb} or (b) a {@item dungeoneer's pack|phb|scimitar}
{@item leather armor|phb|Leather armor}, a set of {@item tinker's tools|phb}, and a {dagger|bpb|dagger}

classFeatures.name: Quick Draw
entries: Beginning at 1st level, your hands are fast as lightning. You have advantage on initiative rolls. You can stow and draw up to any amount of firearms as a free action during your turn.  You may also half your movement speed to reload a firearm.

classFeatures.name: Unarmored Defense
entries: Beginning at 1st level, while you are wearing no armor and not wielding a shield, your AC equals 10 + your Dexterity modifier + your Charisma modifier.

classFeatures.name: Grit and Deeds
entries: Beginning at 2nd level, your time as a gunslinger has made you capable of actions that others would be too unskilled, frightened, or smart to attempt called deeds. Your access to these abilities are accomplished through spending Grit. Your gunslinger level determines the number of points you have, as shown in the Grit Points column of the Gunslinger table.

You can spend these points to fuel various deeds. You start knowing two such features. You learn more deeds as you gain levels in this class as shown in the Deeds Known column.  When you gain a level in this class you can swap one deed for another.
When you spend a grit point, it is unavailable until you finish a long rest. Alternately you regain grit when you score a critical hit with a firearm or reduce a target to 0 hitpoints.
Some of your deeds require your target to make a saving throw to resist the feature's effects. The saving throw DC is calculated as follows:

classFeatures.name: Point Blank
entries: Beginning at 2nd level, attacks made with firearms within 5 feet of you no longer suffer disadvantage.

classFeatures.name: Gunslinger's Trail
entries: At 3rd level, a Gunslinger begins to walk down the path that will define their legend.  Trails are detailed at the end of the class description. The trail you choose grants you features at 3rd level, and again at 6th, 9th, 13th, and 17th level.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeatures.name: Extra Attack
entries: Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn.

classFeatures.name: Gunslinger's Trail feature
entries: At 6th level, you gain a feature granted by your Gunslinger's Trail.

classFeatures.name: Evasion
entries: Starting at 7th Level, you can nimbly dodge out of the way of certain area effects, such as a red dragon's fiery breath or an Ice Storm spell. When you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw, and only half damage if you fail.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeatures.name: Gunslinger's Trail feature
entries: At 9th level, you gain a feature granted by your Gunslinger's Trail.

classFeatures.name: Gunfighter's Sense
entries: At 10th level, your senses become attuned to the presence of others. As long as you aren’t blinded or deafened, creatures within 10 feet of you can’t be hidden from you, and you can’t be surprised.

classFeatures.name: Bad Medicine
entries: Starting at 11th Level, you can roll one additional weapon damage dice when determining the extra damage from a critical hit with a firearm.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeatures.name: Gunslinger's Trail feature
entries: At 13th level, you gain a feature granted by your Gunslinger's Trail.

classFeatures.name: Overwatch
entries: At 14th level, when an enemy moves in or out of within 15 feet of you and you are wielding a firearm you can use your reaction to make an attack of opportunity.

classFeatures.name: Final Stand
entries: When you reach 15th level, when you are reduced to 0 hit points, don’t die outright, and have at least one remaining grit point, you can spend a grit point to use your reaction before you fall unconscious to make an attack roll at an enemy. If the attack hits, you gain hit points equal to 1d8 + your gunslinger level. You are knocked prone. Once you use this feature, you cannot use it again until you complete a long rest.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeatures.name: Gunslinger's Trail feature
entries: At 17th level, you gain a feature granted by your Gunslinger's Trail.

classFeatures.name: Deadshot
entries: At 18th level, your ability to land deadly shots increases with every shot that finds its mark. Each time you hit a creature with a ranged attack using a firearm, the critical range of the weapon increases by 1, to a maximum of 16–20. This effect is applied after the damage is calculated. This effect ends if you miss an attack, are knocked unconscious, if your turn ends and you haven’t attacked a hostile creature since your last turn, or combat ends.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeatures.name: True Grit
entries: At 20th level, when you roll for initiative and have no grit points remaining, you regain 4 grit points.

subclassFeatures.name: Trail of the Desperado
entries: The desperado fights with skill, reflexes, and a quick trigger finger. Her movements are crisp and sharp, faster than the average person can track. Those following this path drill their motions until they surpass normal mortal limits.

entries.name: Shooting Style
entries: When you choose this trail at 3rd level, you adopt a particular style of shooting. Choose one of the following options.
Akimbo Shooting: When wielding two light firearms, you can add your ability score modifier to the damage of the second attack. You can reload both light firearms at once using a bonus action

Breacher: When you make an attack with a firearm with the bludgeoning damage at a creature within 30 feet of you and you roll a 1 or 2 on the damage die, you can reroll the damage die andmust take the new roll, even if the number is a 1 or a 2.
Marksman: When wielding a two-handed firearm with piercing damage, you get a +2 to attack rolls

Dueling: When wielding a one-handed firearm in one hand and no other weapons, you get a +2 bonus to your damage rolls with these weapons. This additional damage only applies for ranged attacks made at creatures within 30 feet of you

entries.name: Dirty Trick
entries: At 6th level, you can throw your enemy off by dashing an object at their face, such as a handful of sand. As a bonus action, choose a creature within 5 feet of you to make Constitution saving throw (Using Deed Save). On a failed save, it is blinded until the end of their next turn.

entries.name: Snapshot
entries: Starting at 9th level, as a reaction when you roll initiative, you can immediately make one ranged weapon attack.

entries.name: Rapid Fire
entries: Starting at 13th level, you can aim and fire with dazzling speed. When you use the Attack action on a target within 30 feet of you you can forgo your two attacks to take shots equal to 2 + your Dexterity modifier (minimum 1) with any firearm you have on your person. You must have available ammunition in the firearms you are holding to make these attacks. The additional shots do not benefit from any modifiers of your regular attacks, but can still misfire. These shots are ineligible for the application of deeds.
Once you use this feature you are not able to do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: High Noon
entries: At 17th level, when you score a critical hit against a creature using a firearm, you can choose for this shot to be a critical shot. The target takes 10d10 additional damage of the same type as the firearm used. Once you use this ability, you must finish a long rest before using it again.

subclassFeatures.name: Trail of the Outlaw
entries: The Outlaw is a Gunslinger who realizes that you need more than just the iron at your side to get through the world.  Using wit and guile to supplement their shooting abilities.

entries.name: Swagger
entries: When you choose this trail at 3rd level, you use your presence to great effect. You gain proficiency in the Intimidation and Persuasion skills, and your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of those skills.

subclassFeatures.name: Dead or Alive
entries: At 6th level, you're made of stern stuff. You gain proficiency in Constitution saving throws and in death saving throws. Upon reducing a target to 0 hit points you also gain temporary hit points equal to your gunslinger level.

entries.name: Intuition
entries: At 9th level, you can spend one minute talking to a creature or observing it to glean knowledge on their tics to gain advantage on any Insight checks to discern intent or disposition on any topic.

entries.name: On the Run
entries: At 9th level, you have learned exactly how to give a pursuer the slip in a chase, whether ducking into an alleyway or weaving through a crowd. You can't be tracked by nonmagical means, unless you choose to leave a trail and will almost always manage to escape when in a chase.

entries.name: Fortune
entries: Starting at the 17th level, some swear you've been kissed by Lady Luck herself. Before you roll a saving throw, you can choose to automatically succeed. Once you use this feature, you must take a long rest before using it again.

subclassFeatures.name: Trail of the Spellshooter
entries: To those unaware of the discovery of black powder, a firearm may seem mystical. An observer could see the fire bursting out of metal tubes, mistaking it for some kind of wizard's spell. Some gunslingers embrace this misconception, combining their marksmanship with arcane prowess.

entries.name: Spellcasting
entries: When you reach 3rd level, you gain the ability to cast spells. See {@book chapter 10|PHB|10} for the general rules of spellcasting and chapter 11 for the {@filter wizard spell list|spells|class=wizard}.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: You learn two cantrips of your choice from the wizard spell list. You learn another wizard cantrip of your choice at 10th level.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Spellshooter Spellcasting table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.
For example, if you know the 1st-level spell {@spell fog cloud} and have a 1st-level and a 2nd-level spell slot available, you can cast {@spell fog cloud} using either slot.

entries.name: Spells Known of 1st-Level and Higher
entries: You know three 1st-level wizard spells of your choice, two of which you must choose from the conjuration and transmutation spells on the wizard spell list.

The Spells Known column of the Spellshooter  Spellcasting table shows when you learn more wizard spells of 1st level or higher. Each of these spells must be an conjuration or transmutation spell of your choice, and must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For instance, when you reach 7th level in this class, you can learn one new spell of 1st or 2nd level.
The spells you learn at 8th, 14th, and 20th level can come from any school of magic.

Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace one of the wizard spells you know with another spell of your choice from the wizard spell list. The new spell must be of a level for which you have spell slots, and it must be an conjuration or transmutation spell, unless you're replacing the spell you gained at 8th, 14th, or 20th level.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for your wizard spells, since you learn your spells through dedicated study and memorization. You use your Intelligence whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Intelligence modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a wizard spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

entries.name: Firearm Focus
entries: When you join this trail at 3rd level,  you can use a firearm as a spellcasting focus.  When you use a firearm as a focus for your spells you can ignore the somatic component of the spell as pulling the trigger of your gun replaces this function.

entries.name: Arcane Arsenal
entries: Beginning at 6th level, firearm attacks that you make count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to non-magical attacks.

entries.name: Spell Artillery
entries: Starting at 9th level, you’ve learned to harness residual magical energy left in the barrel of your gun.  After casting a spell of 1st level or higher, firearm attacks made by you deal an additional 1d6 force damage per the level of spell cast until the end of your next turn.

entries.name: Magical Tracer
entries: At 13th level, after hitting a creature with a spell of 1st level or higher, firearm attacks made against the target gain +1 bonus to hit, per the level of spell cast against the creature.

entries.name: Improved Arcane Arsenal
entries: Upon 17th level, when you cast a spell of 1st level or higher your firearms all magically reload.
